Riley Franco Datasheet as part of Trash Canner for Team 207

Submission: 09, 05, 2025

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This datasheet is intended to support the documentation of the Trash Canner project and record what I personally have done to contribute to this project. It contains my block diagram, component selection, bill of materials, schematic, and power budget.

docs.title: Project Summary
docs.text: The Trash Canner project, linked here, is intended to be a design project for an automatic trashcan with a weight and distance sensor. The weight and distance sensor are connected to LEDs, transitioning from green to red as the trashcan gets progressively more full. Ideally this will alert the user to when the trashcan needs to be emptied, and will assist the user in their daily lives.

docs.title: My Contribution
docs.text: My personal contribution is the motor of the automatic trashcan. After receiving a signal from the motion sensor through my teammate, the motor will automatically open the lid, and after a time, close again (see block diagram for a simpler view of the process, and schematic for a more in-depth view). During this, I had to select various components that my sub-system would use which can be found in the component selection In addtion, I primarily worked on combining the team block diagram, as well creating the team's software proposal. Additionally, I worked on the rest of the assignments, which were more evenly split up between teammates.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This block diagram is intended to convey how this section of the team's project is meant to connect together, as well as the wiring that will take place between the microcontroller and the various components. The connector at the bottom reflects inputs and outputs between the boards of the team members. The arrows indicate the how outputs connect to inputs. In addition, the dotted lines indicate that all components inside are powered by the power source that is highlighted in the corner. The requirements for the project of having an actuator that is connected to a microcontroller and receiving a signal from another subsystem are satisfied with the connection from Hattie's board, and a motor being driven by an h-bridge. The unregulated power supply brings in power for the board to operate, and the voltage regualtor protects the microcontroller, and fulfills the requirement of producing a regulated voltage for power. The test LED and the button fulfill the debugging requirement, and aided in ensuring the subsystem's functionality during testing.

docs.title: Component Selection
docs.text:
Component Selection

Category Chosen Solution Motor Control Fairchild FAN 8100N Motor Pololu 3483 Metal Gearmotor Voltage Regulator Taejin LM7805T Primary Power Supply Tri-Mag 12V 3A

MOTOR CONTROL

Solution Pros Cons

Option 1 Fairchild FAN 8100N $1.16/ each Link to product

  • Fairly cheap
  • Already given from the class
  • DIP that is easy to mount to a PCB
  • Contains heat sinks
  • Fairly narrow operating voltage
  • Expensive shipping rates
Solution Pros Cons

Option 2 DRV8411 Dual H-Bridge Motor Driver $2.30/ each Link to product

  • Can be used for 1 or 2 motors
  • Wide range of operational voltages
  • More expensive
  • Slow shipping time
  • Requires a different setup on a PCB
Solution Pros Cons

Option 3 DRV8870 Brushed-DC Motor Driver $2.09/ each Link to product

  • Fairly small
  • Wide voltage operating range
  • Only operates one motor
  • Requires different PCB layout
  • Operating range lies outside of amount supplied by voltage regulator

Choice: Option 1: Fairchild FAN 8100N Rationale: The FAN8100N is already accessible to the team through the materials given throughout the year, saving on shipping costs, time, and the cost of the unit itself. Additionally, the H-bridge will easily slot into PCBs, and contains heat sinks to keep the part safe and minimize damage and potential replacement.

MOTOR

Solution Pros Cons

Option 1 Pololu 3483 Metal Gearmotor $35.95/ each Link to product

  • Able to provide good torque
  • Good RPM
  • Falls within operating necessities
  • Heavy
  • Somewhat expensive
Solution Pros Cons

Option 2 STANDARD MOTOR 6600 RPM 12V $2.75/ each Link to product

  • Very cheap
  • High RPM
  • Low Strength
  • Ideal Voltage is lower than 12V
Solution Pros Cons

Option 3 Portescap 17N78210E.1 Brushed DC Motor $141.02/ each Link to product

  • High RPM
  • Lightweight
  • Good Torque
  • Very expensive
  • Somewhat large

Choice: Option 1: Pololu 3483 Metal Gearmotor Rationale: The Pololu 3483 has the best features for the price. While the Portescap 17N78210E.1 likely outclasses it in terms of features, the significantly higher price is too much. Conversely, although option 2 is much less expensive, it likely will not be able to handle the necessary operations to complete the project.

Voltage Regulator

Solution Pros Cons

Option 1 Taejin LM7805T $0.33/ each Link to product

  • The team already has these
  • The team already has experience with them
  • Good input voltage range
  • Can only be bought in quantities of 100
  • Very high shipping costs
Solution Pros Cons

Option 2 L7805CV $0.50/ each Link to product

  • Very similar to the component we are familiar with
  • Dynamic pricing making it cheaper at high quantities than other options
  • Multiple options to regulate voltage to
  • Higher cost for fewer ICs, especially with the amount we would need.
Solution Pros Cons

Option 3 TSR 1-2450E $3.40/ each Link to product

  • High input voltage range
  • Able to regulate down to 3.3 or 5v
  • Most expensive
  • Uses an unfamiliar setup

Choice: Option 1: Taejin LM7805T Rationale: This product is the easiest to design the project with, since the team has access and experience with it already. However, in the event of needing to change parts or get replacements, the L7805CV may be a better option. Until those replacements are needed, however, the LM7805T remains the best option.

Primary power supply

Solution Pros Cons

Option 1 ALITOVE 12V 5A $12.99/ each Link to product

  • The power supply fits into a wall outlet
  • The DC power jack fits with the other parts the team has used well.
  • The addition of another power head can allow the team to be more flexible after designing
  • 5A does not quite reach the stall current of the motor
  • It may be more bulky than necessary for our product.
Solution Pros Cons

Option 2 1286-1213-ND $7.99/ each Link to product

  • Good voltage and current rating for the project
  • Multiple suppliers
  • Somewhat expensive shipping
  • Does not include wall outlet adapter
Solution Pros Cons

Option 3 Tri-Mag 12V 3A $10.36/ each Link to product

  • Cheap and easy to order
  • Barrel Jack connection to use the class supplies
  • Variable quality of generic adapters
  • Lower amperage than other options

Choice: Option 3: Tri-Mag 12V 3A Rationale: The DC power jack connector is fairly inexpensive, and supplies 3A of power, which is all that is neccessary to power the system, making it more worth the price.

This schematic is designed to support an understanding of the electrcal systems neccesarry for this component of the project. It illustrateds all the components and wiring needed to create this part of the project, as well as understanding the power requirements for this project. Different componenets of the schematic are sectioned out, each with labels to aid in understanding the schematic at a glance, and some otherwise unknown connections have been labeled.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This power budget is intended to show and ensure that the components of the subsystem can be properly powered with the selected power componenets and regulators. I put all the major componenets of the subsystem into the spreadsheet, seperating them based on their intended power rail, and calculated if the maximum current draw from all components would be less than the amount of current provided by the power sources, with the addition of a 25% safety margin.

docs.title: Conclusions
docs.text: From the prepared Power Budget, it is clear that all componenets will be able to operate under worst-case conditions, ensuring that the design is safe to use and is very unlikely to break as a result of an overdraw of current. The creation of a power budget has informed my componenet selection, ensuring that a proper power supply was chosen in order to accomidate the motor's voltage requirement and current draw.

This PCB is designed to control a motor using the Curiosity Nano microcontroller and an H-bridge. It recieves a signal from my teammates from another board, as well as having a debug pushbutton, a debug LED to ensure the system functions, as well as various test points for different signals to verify their functionality.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This code was used to enable the microcontroller to perform the actions neccesary to properly function as an independant subsystem. It moves a motor for 1 second in one direction, and then moves the motor in the other direction 1 second, using an h-bridge to control the motor.

The code is available to be downloaded as a zip file here,
